greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest period of pseudo-arithmetic progression with initial term 1 and difference 2n-1.
comment: Let x,y be odd numbers. Denote <+> the following binary operation: x<+>y=A000265(x+y). Let a and d be odd numbers. We call a sequence of the form b, b<+>d, (b<+>d)<+>d,... a pseudo-arithmetic progression with the initial term b and the difference d. It is not difficult to prove that every pseudo-arithmetic progression is periodic sequence. This sequence lists smallest periods of pseudo-arithmetic progressions with initial term 1 and difference 2n-1, n=1,2,...
a(n) is the number of distinct odd residues contained in set {1,2,...,2^(2*n-2)} modulo 2*n-1. Thus 2*n-1 is in A001122 iff a(n)=n-1. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jul 18 2010
link: Peter J. C. Moses, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..4096
maple: A179382 := proc(n) local p,k; p := [1] ; for k from 2 do a := pseuAprog( p[-1],2*n-1) ; if not a in p then p := [op(p),a] ; else return nops(p) ; end if; end do: end proc:
mathematica: a[n_] := Module[{d = 2n-1, k=1, t=1}, While[(t = oddres[t+d])>1, k++]; k];
Array[a, 80] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 13 2020, translated from PARI *)
program: print([A179382(n) for n in (1..72)]) # _Peter Luschny_, Oct 07 2017
results.author: _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jul 12 2010
